Posts.Content: I am sorry to hear about your diagnosis. It is so scarey when first told as I remember well. Reading all about my cancer in a book called "What your doctor won't tell you about breast cancer" made feel real better.  I was diagnosed with Stage 11 invasive ductal cancer in my right breast in 2009. It was a 3.50 mil. tumor and cancer grade high. No mets. in nodes.  I had the right breast removed and had four rounds of chemotheraphy and am considered cancer free today. I am 59 now and doing well.  Another great site to go to for great information on any cancer diagnosis is cancer.org cancer.org /cancer/breastcancer/detailedguide/breast-cancer-staging" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.cancer.org /cancer/breastcancer/detailedguide/brea Hope this is helpful.
Posts.Title: Newly Diagnoised

Posts.Content: I had stage 2 invasive ductal Cancer and I chose a mastectomy so I did not have to have radiation. I had only the chemo. I am 6 years out and doing well. I am praying for all here! Commett
Posts.Title: Newly Diagnoised

Posts.Content: How often do any of you reading this see your onocologist after your  chemo treatments were finished and diagnosed as most likely cancer free?
Posts.Title: Post chemotherapy seeing the onocologist

Posts.Content: It is terrible that she may have lied about such an illness, but she must be needing attention very badly. She must be very ill within her mind and soul. I feel sorry for her if this is the case. I also have a neice with this type of affliction and it is hard to deal with. I will keep you and your neice in my prayers. I am a breast cancer survivor and my sister was just diagnosed with stage 4 colon cancer. So sad tonight. God Bless you, Commett
